assessments.task_description:
Students must complete a two page 'project outline' (to be submitted via Turnitin), which clearly states:

1. Agreed research question - make sure you have a well-defined question, and ensure your supervisor and you are in agreement about what it is you will research.

2. Agreed method(s) - Agree with your supervisor which qualitative or quantitative method(s) you will be using to examine the above research question. This should be short but substantive. For example, 'desktop research' is an insufficient description. You should be more illuminating, e.g. 'Comparative case studies of legislation in Queensland, New South Wales, and Victoria. The key focus of comparison will be: aims and effectiveness, with effectiveness judged by a systematic review of the relevant literature.' 

PLEASE NOTE - The Project Outline & Internship Agreement (POIA) Form can be downloaded from the course's Blackboard site (see 'learning resources'), and should be completed and uploaded through Turnitin before the due date.

assessments.task_description:
This assignment requires you to describe any relevant aspects of the organisation's history, its aims, its organisational structure, its working procedures (how it manages its main activities), and the wider context within the organisation is seeking to fulfil its mission.

QPRI interns in second semester can use their Parliamentary Proceedings paper for this submission, and follow the QPRI guidelines rather than the above writing guidelines. All other interns are expected to adhere to the above guidelines when writing their Organisational Context paper.

Submission: This assignment must be submitted to the School of Political Science and International Studies using Turnitin (for marking purposes).

Plagiarism Warning: Please ensure your assignment meets the UQ Academic Integrity standards (see POLSIS Essay Guide and/or UQ's website on Academic Integrity). assessments.task_description:
Interns are expected to present a 7-minute overview of their internship research/report, followed by questions from fellow students and the coordinator for at least 10 minutes. 

Interns are expected to prepare and use a PowerPoint (about 6 slides), and to address the following five points;

1 - The aim(s) of the research

2 - The method(s) being deployed

3 - The main findings (2 slides)

4 - Implications and/or policy-related recommendations

5 - Suggestions for future research

Assessment tasks are intended to evaluate a student’s abilities, skills, and knowledge. This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Please submit your presentation slides via email to Diana (d.mccluskey@uq.edu.au) prior to the due date/time.

assessments.task_description:
Interns are to write a report of around 4000 words, depending on the negotiated topic. The internship report should clearly articulate (1) the broad topic of significance being investigated, (2) the specific central question, (3) the methods used to examine this question, (4) the main research findings, and (5) the implications of these findings for current policy practices and/or stakeholder engagement.

A very good report will typically address these five aspects, so you may want to consider structuring your research report in this way.

The completed report must be submitted (a) to the School of Political Science and International Studies using Turnitin (for marking purposes), with a copy provided to the internship organisation in a format preferred by that organisation.
